Rutherford, Michael wrote:
> In one example I tried was a fairly simple piece of business logic. I needed
> to write some tests around a user belonging to a group.
>  
> I needed at a minimum an implementation of IDfUser and IDfGroup. Due to the
> nature of the beast it is most common to get these from the session
> (IDfSession). As all of these are interfaces it wasn't too bad but each of
> the interfaces extends others and have several hundred methods each. I
> eventually decided that what I was trying to test in this case was
> Documentum logic and that I should just trust the framework.
>   
One quick point: a major appeal of JMock, and the other mocking 
frameworks, as far as I know, is that the number of methods or 
superinterfaces of an interface does not affect the complexity of the 
test, just the number of methods used.  However, I also agree that you 
shouldn't test the framework, just your own code, as much as possible.  
Thanks for the clarification,

    David Saff
